title: Can we please just IP ban players who use bot programs to play the game.
body: It's infuriating when you just want to have a game of ARAM and you lose an otherwise winnable game, because you have a bot on your team that just feeds the entire game. Bots do not help the game, they are not needed and should not be allowed and frankly RIOT should be doing a lot more punishment wise to get rid of these things for good. The fact that these botting programs pretty much change the odds from winning from 50/50 to 80/20 on one team is also completely wrong, as it makes 1 of the 3 available modes luck based instead of skill based effectively . These botters face no punishment outside of their bot accounts being closed, if they doing this it should be an IP ban, because they are just going to make more accounts and keep the bots in a place where they shouldn't be in the first place.

replies.body:
Or we could just ban accounts that are obviously bots in the first place.

The issue is that these bots don't actually get banned.

Man, so did I just dream all those times that I banned bots last year?

Granted neither I nor the automated systems hit them all, also that bots are likely to level fast before we can detect them given how easy it is to hit 30 now.

We've got resources being poured into new methods right now, because whatever we've been doing has, as you've regularly pointed out, not had the desired effect despite the significant time investment thus far.

Do note that IP banning is already known to be a non-workable idea. IP's can be changed, as they often are these days with dynamic IPs being preferred, VPNs can be used.

I mean, and with no offense to individuals that work at riot, you guys don't do nearly enough at all.

These bots are blatantly obvious, doing things that no new player would EVER do (i'm gonna smash QWER on cooldown regardless of who i am and where i am), let alone anyone who is actually not new to the game.

Also i find it slightly concerning how you say this

>so did I just dream all those times that I banned bots last year?

This is actually the last thing i want to hear from a rioter, because this means that likely is not, no single bot takes any bans from automation, and you guys certainly don't have the man power to pull this shit off (unless you actively hire just for this)

You're spot on. The fact that bots still exist at all and are such a consistently complained about issue means we're doing not nearly enough as of yet.
The team that handles automated detection for scripting/cheating also handles automated detection for bots. Automated bans do still exist, this much I know because sometimes when I go to ban some bots manually I find that the automated detection has already picked them up and banned them. Regrettably it's just usually a bit slower than if you were sifting through data manually looking for key indicators and then confirming that through further manual checks.
But the automated bans obviously have a larger scope and can achieve more than any amount of Rioters could manually, but again slower to act due to confidence/accuracy issues.

I do suppose that we've been so much better and faster at addressing cheating/scripting because it has the potential to have a much more negative and larger scope of impact if not given our full attention. Whereas botting is usually at least confined to co-op games or strict MMR ranges in ARAM.
To that end however, the team is actively pouring more effort into the problem, and I'm hopeful that some other stuff coming up will curb the problem.

Now, over the years you've heard me say this before, stuff like "yep it's a problem, it sucks I know! but the team is on the case and working on new detection methods". And while they're working on new methods myself and others will often try to fill the gaps in detection with a few manual efforts here and there.
Gets repetitive doesn't it? But indeed, each time it has been true. But, as with scripting/cheating, it's a constant arms race. Someone develops a cheat, you detect the cheat, then they develop a new cheat or method of employing it and you have to close another loophole or develop new detection and so on it goes.
I'd say this time however, that we're looking to cure the problem to the same degree of effectiveness that we've had with scripting/cheating which has been pretty good. At least I know that is the intent of the team set up to have a crack at it this time.
You and I may be pretty jaded at this point, and gods know I'm as tired of dealing with bots as anyone, but I'm actually hopeful that we're gonna take a more significant and permanent chunk out of the problem in 2018.

And isn't that just the root of it. Bots can be pretty sophisticated these days, and some players pretty bot like. You can't draw a definite line, which means there's always going to be some bots that stick around far longer than anyone would like.

What if Riot had a way of  seeing actual player accounts games, and in turn revealed bots, would that not increase the chance of bots being detected and bans?

I'm not explaining this well, but some form of way where system/man can see what the players see, so that at the end of the game you can instaban the bots, since they're very easy to spot *cough* cleanse/barrier, Run it down *cough*

Riot can see replays, but such a thing would require manual review of every single reported bot, which just isn't possible even if you exclude any false reports. The volume of bots and the ease with which they are created is the problem. If you detect certain behaviours, then the bots adapt and no longer give those cues. If you detect a certain software or pattern, again they simply adapt.

Having cleanse/barrier might be a thing that bots do, but it's also something some players do. Should those players not be allowed to play off meta the way they want just because it's a behaviour that bots share? It's mostly obvious to anyone actually in the game who is or isn't a bot, but manual reviews aren't and never will be the answer to the bot problem. It's just not sustainable.
